intro: Psammisia hookeriana, commonly known as the Hooker's sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming structure with fleshy, succulent leaves that help it conserve water. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in summer, adding ornamental value to its habitat. It thrives in well-drained sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to withstand high temperatures and drought. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is sometimes cultivated in xeriscapes and botanical gardens.
